newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - April 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - April 21.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN

Queensland reserve hooker Brendan Cannon was suspended from playing in the Australian Rugby Union competition for four months for stomping on NSW winger Alistair Murdoch during Saturday's Super League 12 match. The length of the suspension is unprecedented in Australian rugby history. Page 27.

Australian Darren Mercer yesterday continued a family tradition by beating world champion Nathan Meyer to retain the Australian Open Ironman title in the national surf lifesaving championships at Kurrawa Beach. His younger brother Dean won the title in 1995 before Darren's first win in 1996. Page 29.

15-year-old Australian Kristy Ellem has win the 100m and 200m breaststroke at the world short course swimming championships in Gothenburg, Sweden. Ellem who is competing in her first international competition became Australia's first dual gold medallist t the event. Australia is currently leading the medal tally after three days of competition. page 29.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

The Australian Rugby Union Super 12 match between the two rival states of New South Wales and Queensland last Saturday erupted into a on-field brawl resulting in ten players from both sides having penalties brought against them. Queensland won the match 26-16. Page 35

The Australian Football League (AFL) match between the Sydney Swans and St Kilda on Saturday saw the emergence of a new football star. Sydney Swans new goal-kicker Craig O'Brien was instrumental in the Swan's 127 to 81 win with his tally of five goals. age 29.

The Australian National Basketball League continues to be a tight competition with the Sydney Kings losing their second match in a row to the North Melbourne Giants last Saturday. The Sydney Kings were defeated 94-92 in a tight match where the outcome wa in-doubt right down until to the buzzer sounded. Page 28.
THE AGE

The Australian Football League (AFL) team Port Adelaide defeated the Adelaide Crows by 11 points yesterday where the two South Australian teams met for the first all-state AFL clash at Adelaide's Football Park. The match had had roused sectarian conflict within the city and was played to a capacity crowd of over 47,000. Page 2.

Australian commentators have called for a review of the state of umpiring in the Australian Football League (AFL) competition. Umpires are facing increasing criticism from players, coaches and spectators at the fast pace they allow games to proceed at an for gross errors in judgement which have cost teams badly needed championship points. Page 6.

Australian Michael Doohan won the 500 cc Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday beating teammate and arch-rival Alex Criville in the process. Doohan completed the 21-lap race in 45 minutes and 11.995 seconds. It was the first race he had won since 1992 riding a onda at the Suzuka circuit. page 17.
THE HERALD SUN

Prominent Australian Football League (AFL) team Essendon are set to play the Anzac Day (April 25) match against arch-rivals Collingwood with only a four day break from their last game and a team riddled with injuries including star forward James Hird andMichael Long who have been sidelined with long-term leg injuries. The Anzac Day match is a highlight of the AFL competition. Page 88.

Australian hose racing has seen the emergence of a new star with the win last Saturday by 17-year-old jockey Michael Pritchard in the Asia-Pacific jockey challenge. Pritchard beat a field of eleven internationally experienced jockeys to win the event and is now being closely watched by the racing scene to see if he can continue his success. Page 81.

Australian netball is currently in turmoil with a major team the Melbourne Kestrels re-structuring its line-up. Despite the team's recent string of victories, Coach Lisa Alexander explained the review of the starting seven players by saying that the tea needed to consider constant changes to match the strengths of the different teams it opposed. Page 82.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Australian swimmers are continuing their run of success at the world short course swimming championships in Gothenburg, Sweden. Apart from Kristy Ellem wins in the 100m and 200m breaststroke, 15-year-old Natasha Bowran won silver in the 400m freestyle an Scott Goodman won bronze in the mens 200m butterfly despite being ill with flu. Page 39.

Commonwealth Games gold medallist Australian Stacey Gartrell yesterday won her second Australian Surf Life Saving Championships at the Gold Coast. She beat off an international crowd including former world swimming champion Simone Cotter and New Zealand hampion Kim Tunnell both of whom finished second and third respectively. Page 29.

Soccer Australia has been criticised by commentators for continuing to support referee Eddie Lennie who has been slammed for his performance during the national competition the Ericsson Cup. Lennie continues to receive first-grade appointments despite his perceived glaring errors in judgement. Page 26.
